awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Sample Selection for Multi-Level Data Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
General Abstract
An important part of political science research entails the analysis of events data in which the researcher accounts for when events occur, how often they occur, and tries to explain why they occur.  Examples of interest to political scientists include topics like wars, mass protests, and coups, for instance.  One of the problems associated with this type of research is that the event being observed is the product of a number of other factors or conditions. As a consequence, the researcher may not be able to identify the actual causes or the relative contributions of a set of causal factors for that outcome.  Since the analysis of particular events is of such interest to political scientists, it is important to develop methods that allow researchers to draw the correct conclusions about how such events came to occur.  The research team proposes to develop a statistical method to overcome the problems associated with events data analysis.  The method has the potential to improve our understanding of how important types of events come to occur, making  it of great interest to scholars across a range of social sciences.  The research project will also provide a significant educational component as the team proposes to involve undergraduate students in the research experience. 

Technical Abstract
The PI's note that much of the events data collected in the social sciences is the product of a structural data generation process that generally remains unanalyzed.  As a result the observed events are correlated with a number of covariates.  Statistical analyses of such data may lead to biased inferences if not appropriately addressed.  These problems are of particular concern for small-n, or area-based research.  The PI's propose to develop a theoretically-informed, statistical approach to how data is selected structurally.  The project consists of three components.  First, they develop an estimation procedure for repeated observations at higher levels of analysis with structural data. Second, they will produce work that bridges different periods of time-based aggregation across levels.  Third, they extend the structural selection frame to move beyond two-level structures.  Successfully developing the procedure will help to improve the collection and analysis of data, thereby helping to reduce the trade-off between thick descriptive approaches focusing on a few cases and thinly-informative operationalizations of variables in large-n studies.  The work will have applications beyond political science, appealing to scholars in a number of social scientific disciplines.  The project will provide important pedagogical benefits as the  PI's will involve undergraduate students in the research.

por.por_cntn:
Despite the emerging focus on developing data-based policy responses to problems of conflict, there has not been the necessary recognition that inferences from analyses using much of these events data are incorrect, owing to a dependence on non-random observations in which the events data are collected. Our grant sought to change this by developing statistical methods to understand and properly model the data generation process for several conflict-related issues.  These methods would then serve as baseline tools for studies in other fields with similar issues. 

Two peer-reviewed articles have been published, with others in development, that demonstrate the approach and how it affects inferences. One study, published in the Journal of Politics, examined the relationship between joint democracy and alliances.  Whereas most previous work suggests that democracies are more reliable partners, we argue and demonstrate that democracies only appear as more reliable owing to their placement in a different structural environment than that which nondemocracies find themselves.  Because states need to be at peace in order for democracy to emerge and flourish, the alliances in which democracies participate are already likely to be more peaceful—because they have few dangerous issues threatening them. Since factors about alliance reliability can only be collected for states in an alliance, these data suffer from a structural induced form of non-random observation. We used a statistical technique called a split-population logit to correct for this, as well as conducted a number of additional tests to further validate the findings. We then suggested, and offered some preliminary analyses, for how the non-random nature of democratization and consolidation can be used in other areas.

A second study, also published in the Journal of Politics, assessed the action-reaction process of competing major powers in terms of their troop placements. We argue that to create, consolidate, and expand their spheres of influence around the world, while at the same time trying to prevent their major power rivals from doing the same. Here, the simultaneity and multiple levels of analyses created difficulties in inference. We combine our insights on structural environments and varying levels of analysis with network analysis to model the theorized processes. 

We have several other manuscripts in various stages of review, and each demonstrates how different data-generation processes need to be and could be modeled.  The grant was instrumental in developing both the arguments and the methods used to test these arguments.
